Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Ultracold Molecular Ions Prepared via Sympathetic Cooling - A New Frontier for Quantum Interactions and Fundamental Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Ultracold molecular ions prepared via sympathetic cooling : a new frontier for quantum interactions and fundamental physics
Eric R. Hudson, UCLA, Los Angeles, CA 90095

This CAREER award supports the development of techniques to open and explore a new frontier in physics: ultracold polar molecular ions. Recent work has shown that by spatially overlapping a cloud of ultracold calcium atoms with a molecular ion trap, it is now possible to produce samples of cooled polar molecular ions. It is expected that samples such as these will lead to significant technological and fundamental advancements, including the study and possible control of chemistry in the quantum regime, the implementation of a scalable quantum computer, new probes of quantum matter and charge transport, understanding the formation of interstellar clouds, and precision measurement of molecular structure for test of fundamental physics. Thus, the main research objective and intellectual merit of this project is to further optimize the methods of cold polar molecular production and begin developing the techniques necessary to enable the expected technological and fundamental advancements.

In concert with this research effort, this CAREER award also supports an effort to increase the broader impact of the work by partnering with the UCLA Graduate School of Education's Center X Science Project to develop a series of inquiry-based, hands-on experiments to help local K-12 schools meet the Science Content Standards for California Public Schools. Center X partners with well over 100 local schools, helping them to improve their curriculum and teaching strategies, but currently needs help in developing relevant, inquiry-based physics experiments. Since research shows that when coursework is coupled with hands-on experience, students learn more effectively, retain knowledge longer, and develop higher-order skills with the added benefit of reaching a diversity of students, this lack of curriculum must be addressed. To combat this deficiency, work under this CAREER award will develop a hands-on laboratory curriculum for high schools students closely tied to the research performed in our laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a hybrid atom-ion trapping system, composed of a linear ion trap and magneto-optical trap. A technique for integrating time-of-flight mass spectrometry was developed and built into the system. Using laser cooling and sympathetic cooling, this system allowed the study of cold chemical reactions between atoms and ions and resulted in the first synthesis of a mixed hypermetallic oxide molecule.  It has also taken the first steps toward the production of cold, quantum-state-selected polar molecular ion samples.

 

These results have allowed a greater understanding of chemical reaction processes, cold atom-ion collision physics, and shown a credible path forward to the production of cold, quantum-state-selected polar molecular ions. These molecular ions are an attractive candidate for robust quantum computing platform. This work has been disseminated through public lectures and journal publications.

 

Through this project we have be able to train six undergraduate students, roughly half from underrepresented groups, in modern AMO researcher. All but one of those students has gone, or plans to go, to graduate school in a STEM field. We have also trained five graduate students. Three of those students have finished their PhD and are now employed in careers in science and technology. The other two graduate students are completing their PhD’s on the project. The project has trained four postdoctoral researchers, who have either gone onto permanent positions or are still employed at  UCLA.

 

We have also partnered with a local high school to create a hands-on lecture/experiment for high school physics and chemistry classes. The lesson focused on concepts of thermodynamics that could be connected to our research. Specifically, the students used solar panels to power the electrolysis of water and then used the H2 and O2 that were produced to power a fuel cell car. The local high school serves a predominantly underrepresented community in Southern Los Angeles and was in need of active learning type science curriculum. Our group provided them with the materials, a lesson plan, and background material for the educators. We also gave a workshop on how to teach the material and use the equipment to the science teachers.
